elements.content: High-throughput metabolic analysis based on laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry exhibits broad prospects in the field of large-scale precise medicine, for which the assisted ionization ability of the matrix becomes a determining step. In this work, the gold-decorated hierarchical metal oxide heterojunctions (dubbed Au/HMOHs) are proposed as a matrix for extracting urine metabolic fingerprints (UMFs) of primary nephrotic syndrome (PNS). The hierarchical heterojunctions are simply derived from metal–organic framework (MOF)-on-MOF hybrids, and the native built-in electric field from heterojunctions plus the extra Au decoration provides remarkable ionization efficiency, attaining high-quality UMFs. These UMFs are employed to realize precise diagnosis, subtype classification, and effective prognosis evaluation of PNS by appropriate machine learning, all with 100% accurate ratios. Moreover, a high-confidence marker panel for PNS diagnosis is constructed. Interestingly, all panel metabolite markers present obviously uniform downregulation in PNS compared to healthy controls, shedding light on mechanism exploration and pathway analysis. This work drives the application of metabolomics toward precision medicine.
elements.clean_text: High-throughput metabolic analysis based on laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry exhibits broad prospects in the field of large-scale precise medicine, for which the assisted ionization ability of the matrix becomes a determining step. In this work, the gold-decorated hierarchical metal oxide heterojunctions (dubbed Au/HMOHs) are proposed as a matrix for extracting urine metabolic fingerprints (UMFs) of primary nephrotic syndrome (PNS). The hierarchical heterojunctions are simply derived from metal-organic framework (MOF)-on-MOF hybrids, and the native built-in electric field from heterojunctions plus the extra Au decoration provides remarkable ionization efficiency, attaining high-quality UMFs. These UMFs are employed to realize precise diagnosis, subtype classification, and effective prognosis evaluation of PNS by appropriate machine learning, all with 100% accurate ratios. Moreover, a high-confidence marker panel for PNS diagnosis is constructed. Interestingly, all panel metabolite markers present obviously uniform downregulation in PNS compared to healthy controls, shedding light on mechanism exploration and pathway analysis. This work drives the application of metabolomics toward precision medicine.

elements.content: Primary nephrotic syndrome (PNS) is a renal disease with unclear mechanisms and complex pathological types, which is normally accompanied by various lesions in the capillary walls of the glomeruli and characterized by edema, heavy proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia. Severe complications such as thromboembolism and acute renal failure appear commonly along with PNS progress, which are the main factors for high mortality and disability rates. Timely and precise monitoring and detection of PNS are beneficial to the formulation and implementation of treatment protocols, positively improving the prognosis and preventing complications. Currently, renal puncture plays a gold standard role in PNS diagnosis and pathological typing, whereas it is an invasive operation with limited safety and low acceptance among patients, resulting in severe limitations in clinical application. As a consequence, the clinics highly expect a new approach with simplicity, rapidness, high precision, strong universality, and noninvasiveness to replace traumatic renal puncture.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Primary nephrotic syndrome (PNS) is a renal disease with unclear mechanisms and complex pathological types, which is normally accompanied by various lesions in the capillary walls of the glomeruli and characterized by edema, heavy proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia. Severe complications such as thromboembolism and acute renal failure appear commonly along with PNS progress, which are the main factors for high mortality and disability rates. Timely and precise monitoring and detection of PNS are beneficial to the formulation and implementation of treatment protocols, positively improving the prognosis and preventing complications. Currently, renal puncture plays a gold standard role in PNS diagnosis and pathological typing, whereas it is an invasive operation with limited safety and low acceptance among patients, resulting in severe limitations in clinical application. As a consequence, the clinics highly expect a new approach with simplicity, rapidness, high precision, strong universality, and noninvasiveness to replace traumatic renal puncture.

elements.content: Metabolic analysis has been considered as the ideal substitution of traditional approaches due to that metabolites (less than 1000 Da) reflect changes of end products in gene-derived downstream effects. Laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry (LDI-MS) stands out for high throughput, analysis speed within seconds, simple sample preparation, and sample consumption at the micro/nanoliter level, thereby being the hot research topic in metabolic analysis-based precise medicine. Nevertheless, LDI-MS performance relies on the matrix. Conventional organic matrices including α-cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid (CHCA) and 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid (DHB) prefer to produce interference signals in the low mass range, leading to huge difficulty in metabolite detection. The introduction of nanomaterials with good ultraviolet absorption capacity well avoids the background interference but only provides inadequate ionization efficiency for low-abundance metabolites, which is far away from clinical application. The component singleness may be the ringleader leading to the unsatisfactory separation of electron–hole pairs on the interface of the matrix.
elements.clean_text: Metabolic analysis has been considered as the ideal substitution of traditional approaches due to that metabolites (less than 1000 Da) reflect changes of end products in gene-derived downstream effects. Laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry (LDI-MS) stands out for high throughput, analysis speed within seconds, simple sample preparation, and sample consumption at the micro/nanoliter level, thereby being the hot research topic in metabolic analysis-based precise medicine. Nevertheless, LDI-MS performance relies on the matrix. Conventional organic matrices including α-cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid (CHCA) and 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid (DHB) prefer to produce interference signals in the low mass range, leading to huge difficulty in metabolite detection. The introduction of nanomaterials with good ultraviolet absorption capacity well avoids the background interference but only provides inadequate ionization efficiency for low-abundance metabolites, which is far away from clinical application. The component singleness may be the ringleader leading to the unsatisfactory separation of electron-hole pairs on the interface of the matrix.

elements.content: As is well known, the matrix interface is the location that realizes generation, separation, transfer, and recombination of electron–hole pairs, while the recombination rate on the unitary interface is normally faster than trapping and transfer rates. In this regard, researchers made much effort on the fabrication of binary matrices, such as polymer@Ag and COF-V@Au, with the purpose of applying noble metal nanoparticles as electron sinks to reduce the recombination rate. Moreover, noble metals are capable of improving LDI efficiency because of their surface plasma resonance effect that can generate large densities of hot electrons under excitation conditions, which is beneficial to improve the adsorption and desorption of metabolites. Drawing inspiration from the above-mentioned studies, it is very much possible that the transfer and separation efficiency of electron–hole pairs can be improved by adjusting the number and type of interfaces. The metal oxide p–n junction consisting of p- and n-type semiconductors has been regarded as an effective structure for charge trapping and separation, since the heterojunction can form a built-in electric field at the two-phase interface to hinder the recombination of electron–hole pairs. Generally, the built-in electric field will lead p-zone electrons to go through the p–n junction into the n-zone and n-zone holes to go into the p-zone when excited by the appropriate light source. Furthermore, the high thermal capacity, high photothermal conversion, and low thermal conductivity of matrix materials favor photoionization and thermally driven desorption during LDI-MS, which can reduce thermal dissipation from materials themselves to the target plate and facilitate high-efficiency desorption of the analytes. In this respect, metal oxides are relatively superior, hence receiving extensive attention in the detection of various low-molecular compounds. As a result, the metal oxide heterojunction is worthy of being anticipated.
elements.clean_text: As is well known, the matrix interface is the location that realizes generation, separation, transfer, and recombination of electron-hole pairs, while the recombination rate on the unitary interface is normally faster than trapping and transfer rates. In this regard, researchers made much effort on the fabrication of binary matrices, such as polymer@Ag and COF-V@Au, with the purpose of applying noble metal nanoparticles as electron sinks to reduce the recombination rate. Moreover, noble metals are capable of improving LDI efficiency because of their surface plasma resonance effect that can generate large densities of hot electrons under excitation conditions, which is beneficial to improve the adsorption and desorption of metabolites. Drawing inspiration from the above-mentioned studies, it is very much possible that the transfer and separation efficiency of electron-hole pairs can be improved by adjusting the number and type of interfaces. The metal oxide p-n junction consisting of p- and n-type semiconductors has been regarded as an effective structure for charge trapping and separation, since the heterojunction can form a built-in electric field at the two-phase interface to hinder the recombination of electron-hole pairs. Generally, the built-in electric field will lead p-zone electrons to go through the p-n junction into the n-zone and n-zone holes to go into the p-zone when excited by the appropriate light source. Furthermore, the high thermal capacity, high photothermal conversion, and low thermal conductivity of matrix materials favor photoionization and thermally driven desorption during LDI-MS, which can reduce thermal dissipation from materials themselves to the target plate and facilitate high-efficiency desorption of the analytes. In this respect, metal oxides are relatively superior, hence receiving extensive attention in the detection of various low-molecular compounds. As a result, the metal oxide heterojunction is worthy of being anticipated.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been shown to transform into metal oxides after a convenient heat treatment. In addition, a new family of MOF-on-MOF hybrid materials can be easily formed by conjugation of two or more MOF units, which hold great potential in fabricating binary or polynary metal oxides. According to previous reports, zeolitic imidazolate framework-L (ZIF-L) and zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (ZIF-67) can be simply transformed into ZnO and Co3O4, respectively, two typical representatives of n-type and p-type metal oxide semiconductors, respectively. Moreover, zinc oxide and cobalt oxide prefer to be electron and hole collectors, respectively. In consequence, in this work, we attempt to fabricate MOF-on-MOF hybrid materials through using ZIF-L as a substrate for the epitaxial growth of ZIF-67 and then acquire the hierarchical metal oxide heterojunctions (dubbed HMOHs) via facile calcination. In the meanwhile, we introduce the Au nanoparticles onto the surface of HMOHs. The resultant Au-decorated HMOHs (Au/HMOHs) are applied to assist LDI-MS to conduct urinary metabolic analysis of PNS (). Based on the extracted urinary metabolic fingerprints (UMFs), the PNS diagnosis, typing, and prognosis evaluation can be perfectly realized. The results suggest that this high-throughput and noninvasive approach is feasible in the accurate detection of diseases or even their prognosis evaluation.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been shown to transform into metal oxides after a convenient heat treatment. In addition, a new family of MOF-on-MOF hybrid materials can be easily formed by conjugation of two or more MOF units, which hold great potential in fabricating binary or polynary metal oxides. According to previous reports, zeolitic imidazolate framework-L (ZIF-L) and zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (ZIF-67) can be simply transformed into ZnO and Co3O4, respectively, two typical representatives of n-type and p-type metal oxide semiconductors, respectively. Moreover, zinc oxide and cobalt oxide prefer to be electron and hole collectors, respectively. In consequence, in this work, we attempt to fabricate MOF-on-MOF hybrid materials through using ZIF-L as a substrate for the epitaxial growth of ZIF-67 and then acquire the hierarchical metal oxide heterojunctions (dubbed HMOHs) via facile calcination. In the meanwhile, we introduce the Au nanoparticles onto the surface of HMOHs. The resultant Au-decorated HMOHs (Au/HMOHs) are applied to assist LDI-MS to conduct urinary metabolic analysis of PNS (). Based on the extracted urinary metabolic fingerprints (UMFs), the PNS diagnosis, typing, and prognosis evaluation can be perfectly realized. The results suggest that this high-throughput and noninvasive approach is feasible in the accurate detection of diseases or even their prognosis evaluation.

elements.content: Schematic illustrations of (a) synthetic strategy of Au/HMOHs and (b) urine metabolic fingerprints based on Au/HMOH-assisted LDI-MS for PNS diagnosis, typing, and prognosis evaluation.
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic illustrations of (a) synthetic strategy of Au/HMOHs and (b) urine metabolic fingerprints based on Au/HMOH-assisted LDI-MS for PNS diagnosis, typing, and prognosis evaluation.

elements.content: ZIF-L/ZIF-67 and HMOHs were synthesized according to the reported method, and the related details are displayed in Supporting Information. For the synthesis of tetrapetalous Au/HMOHs, 100 mL of HAuCl4·4H2O solution (1 mM) was poured into a 250 mL three-necked flask, and then, HMOHs (50 mg) were added and mixed thoroughly at room temperature. After that, the mixture was heated to boil. Subsequently, 10 mL of Na3C6H5O7·2H2O solution (38.8 mM) was rapidly poured and stirred vigorously for 10 min. The resulting products were washed three times using ultrapure water and dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C overnight for further experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of Au/HMOHs

ZIF-L/ZIF-67 and HMOHs were synthesized according to the reported method, and the related details are displayed in Supporting Information. For the synthesis of tetrapetalous Au/HMOHs, 100 mL of HAuCl4⋅4H2O solution (1 mM) was poured into a 250 mL three-necked flask, and then, HMOHs (50 mg) were added and mixed thoroughly at room temperature. After that, the mixture was heated to boil. Subsequently, 10 mL of Na3C6H5O7⋅2H2O solution (38.8 mM) was rapidly poured and stirred vigorously for 10 min. The resulting products were washed three times using ultrapure water and dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C overnight for further experiments.

elements.content: All the urine samples were collected from the Huashan Hospital of Fudan University and the Zhongshan Hospital of Fudan University. The total 328 urine samples were divided into three groups including 125 healthy controls (HC), 141 primary nephrotic syndrome (PNS), among which the latter contains 32 subtype minimal change diseases (MCD) and 109 subtype membranous nephropathy without treatment (MNWT), and 62 samples (44 partial remission of MN, PRMN, and 18 complete remission of MN, CRMN) as a prognosis group (PG), wherein diagnostic MN has been treated clinically. All urine samples were stored in a −80 °C refrigerator and freeze-thawed at 4 °C prior to LDI-MS analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Collection and Preparation of Samples

All the urine samples were collected from the Huashan Hospital of Fudan University and the Zhongshan Hospital of Fudan University. The total 328 urine samples were divided into three groups including 125 healthy controls (HC), 141 primary nephrotic syndrome (PNS), among which the latter contains 32 subtype minimal change diseases (MCD) and 109 subtype membranous nephropathy without treatment (MNWT), and 62 samples (44 partial remission of MN, PRMN, and 18 complete remission of MN, CRMN) as a prognosis group (PG), wherein diagnostic MN has been treated clinically. All urine samples were stored in a -80 °C refrigerator and freeze-thawed at 4 °C prior to LDI-MS analysis.

elements.content: The synthesis route of Au/HMOHs is displayed in a. Briefly, MOF-on-MOF hybrids are constructed at room temperature using 2-methylimidazole as organic ligands and zinc nitrate hexahydrate and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate as metal ion sources, for subsequent calcination and gold nanoparticle decoration. In theory, the MOF-on-MOF (ZIF-L/ZIF-67) hybrids should display excellent crystallinity due to the designed epitaxial growth mode. As seen in Figure S1a, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of ZIF-L/ZIF-67 presents two characteristic sets of peaks representing ZIF-L and ZIF-67, proving the feasibility of the design growth mode. Additionally, all the specific peaks of ZnO at 31.84, 34.53, 36.33, 47.38, 56.50, 62.90, 67.69, and 69.21° and characteristic peaks of Co3O4 at 19.13, 31.30, 36.90, 38.60, 44.79, 56.03, 59.45, and 65.30° are included without other impure peaks in the corresponding PXRD pattern of HMOHs (Figure S1b), indicating the complete transformation from ZIF-L/ZIF-67 to HMOHs.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization of Tetrapetalous Au/HMOHs

The synthesis route of Au/HMOHs is displayed in a. Briefly, MOF-on-MOF hybrids are constructed at room temperature using 2-methylimidazole as organic ligands and zinc nitrate hexahydrate and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate as metal ion sources, for subsequent calcination and gold nanoparticle decoration. In theory, the MOF-on-MOF (ZIF-L/ZIF-67) hybrids should display excellent crystallinity due to the designed epitaxial growth mode. As seen in Figure S1a, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of ZIF-L/ZIF-67 presents two characteristic sets of peaks representing ZIF-L and ZIF-67, proving the feasibility of the design growth mode. Additionally, all the specific peaks of ZnO at 31.84, 34.53, 36.33, 47.38, 56.50, 62.90, 67.69, and 69.21° and characteristic peaks of Co3O4 at 19.13, 31.30, 36.90, 38.60, 44.79, 56.03, 59.45, and 65.30° are included without other impure peaks in the corresponding PXRD pattern of HMOHs (Figure S1b), indicating the complete transformation from ZIF-L/ZIF-67 to HMOHs.

elements.content: Field emission transmission electron microscopy (FETEM) images in a,b show that both MOF-on-MOF hybrids and HMOHs look like tetrapetalous crossed nanosheets; the evident difference is that HMOHs present a rougher surface because of the calcination process. After gold nanoparticle decoration, the resultant Au/HMOHs maintain the crossed-nanosheet morphology (c), and lots of black dots newly appear on the rough surface, indicating the successful decoration of Au nanoparticles. Moreover, elemental mapping results in d,e indicate the hierarchical structures of Co3O4 and ZnO owing to the MOF-on-MOF design, namely the duplex growth of ZIF-67 on ZIF-L, which can be further proved by the typical PXRD patterns in Figure S1. All the above-mentioned factors are conducive to the separation of electron–hole pairs. Furthermore, the lattice fringe images from high-resolution FETEM in f show the typical interplanar spacing of 0.263, 0.221, and 0.233 nm, manifesting the existence of ZnO(002), Co3O4(111), and Au(111), respectively.
elements.clean_text: Field emission transmission electron microscopy (FETEM) images in a,b show that both MOF-on-MOF hybrids and HMOHs look like tetrapetalous crossed nanosheets; the evident difference is that HMOHs present a rougher surface because of the calcination process. After gold nanoparticle decoration, the resultant Au/HMOHs maintain the crossed-nanosheet morphology (c), and lots of black dots newly appear on the rough surface, indicating the successful decoration of Au nanoparticles. Moreover, elemental mapping results in d,e indicate the hierarchical structures of Co3O4 and ZnO owing to the MOF-on-MOF design, namely the duplex growth of ZIF-67 on ZIF-L, which can be further proved by the typical PXRD patterns in Figure S1. All the above-mentioned factors are conducive to the separation of electron-hole pairs. Furthermore, the lattice fringe images from high-resolution FETEM in f show the typical interplanar spacing of 0.263, 0.221, and 0.233 nm, manifesting the existence of ZnO(002), Co3O4(111), and Au(111), respectively.

elements.content: FETEM images with different magnifications of (a) ZIF-L/ZIF-67, (b) HMOHs, and (c) Au/HMOHs. Elemental mapping images of (d) HMOHs and (e) Au/HMOHs showing Zn in blue, Co in purple, O in green, Au in yellow, and overlapped image. (f) High-resolution FETEM image of Au/HMOHs. (g) UV–visible spectra of ZnO, HMOHs, and Au/HMOHs.
elements.clean_text: 2  FETEM images with different magnifications of (a) ZIF-L/ZIF-67, (b) HMOHs, and (c) Au/HMOHs. Elemental mapping images of (d) HMOHs and (e) Au/HMOHs showing Zn in blue, Co in purple, O in green, Au in yellow, and overlapped image. (f) High-resolution FETEM image of Au/HMOHs. (g) UV-visible spectra of ZnO, HMOHs, and Au/HMOHs.

elements.content: Favorable optical performance is one prerequisite for an outstanding MALDI matrix who needs to be equipped with strong absorption ability at 355 nm, the laser wavelength of MALDI. An ultraviolet/visible (UV/Vis) absorption spectrometer was applied to characterize ZnO, HMOHs, and Au/HMOHs. As shown in g, Au/HMOHs exhibit the strongest absorption at 355 nm compared with HMOHs and ZnO, indicating that Au/HMOHs will transfer the photon energy of the UV laser to the analyte more efficiently. This should be attributed to the proper adjustment of the number and type of matrix interfaces. Notably, a negative metal ion layer on the surface can favor the formation of cation adducts; the zeta potential measurement was implemented to figure out the surface charge distribution of Au/HMOHs. From Figure S2, the zeta potential significantly decreases to −17.4 mV after decoration of Au nanoparticles, suggesting that Au/HMOHs are more likely to obtain protons or combine with Na+ and K+ to form [M + H]+, [M + Na]+, and [M + K]+ signals in the MALDI-MS positive ion mode, which is conducive to the clear signal recognition of target molecules.
elements.clean_text: Favorable optical performance is one prerequisite for an outstanding MALDI matrix who needs to be equipped with strong absorption ability at 355 nm, the laser wavelength of MALDI. An ultraviolet/visible (UV/Vis) absorption spectrometer was applied to characterize ZnO, HMOHs, and Au/HMOHs. As shown in g, Au/HMOHs exhibit the strongest absorption at 355 nm compared with HMOHs and ZnO, indicating that Au/HMOHs will transfer the photon energy of the UV laser to the analyte more efficiently. This should be attributed to the proper adjustment of the number and type of matrix interfaces. Notably, a negative metal ion layer on the surface can favor the formation of cation adducts; the zeta potential measurement was implemented to figure out the surface charge distribution of Au/HMOHs. From Figure S2, the zeta potential significantly decreases to -17.4 mV after decoration of Au nanoparticles, suggesting that Au/HMOHs are more likely to obtain protons or combine with Na+ and K+ to form [M + H]+, [M + Na]+, and [M + K]+ signals in the MALDI-MS positive ion mode, which is conducive to the clear signal recognition of target molecules.

elements.content: Primarily, we performed LDI-MS analysis of Au/HMOHs without analytes to evaluate the elimination ability toward background noises. Other matrices including CHCA, DHB, and HMOHs were applied for comparison. From a, it is observed that Au/HMOHs, HMOHs, and ZnO present a much cleaner background than organic matrices. Afterward, we selected glucose (Glc) as a model molecule to investigate the concentration effect of Au/HMOHs ranging from 0.1 to 5 mg mL–1; the results of three independent trials show that the optimal concentration was 1 mg mL–1 (p < 0.05, Figure S3), which was adopted in the following experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Performance Investigation of Au/HMOHs for Standard Metabolites

Primarily, we performed LDI-MS analysis of Au/HMOHs without analytes to evaluate the elimination ability toward background noises. Other matrices including CHCA, DHB, and HMOHs were applied for comparison. From a, it is observed that Au/HMOHs, HMOHs, and ZnO present a much cleaner background than organic matrices. Afterward, we selected glucose (Glc) as a model molecule to investigate the concentration effect of Au/HMOHs ranging from 0.1 to 5 mg mL-1; the results of three independent trials show that the optimal concentration was 1 mg mL-1 (p < 0.05, Figure S3), which was adopted in the following experiments.

elements.content: (a) Background spectra of Au/HMOHs, HMOHs, DHB, and CHCA. (b) MS spectra of the standard metabolite mixture and (c) corresponding mean intensities of 11 adducted signals in replicates, using Au/HMOHs, HMOHs, DHB, and CHCA as matrices. The comparison spectra and the corresponding average signal intensities of (d, g) Asp, (e, h) Glc, and (f, i) Arg, using Au/HMOHs, HMOHs, and ZnO as matrices. The error bars are calculated as the standard deviation of three experiments.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Background spectra of Au/HMOHs, HMOHs, DHB, and CHCA. (b) MS spectra of the standard metabolite mixture and (c) corresponding mean intensities of 11 adducted signals in replicates, using Au/HMOHs, HMOHs, DHB, and CHCA as matrices. The comparison spectra and the corresponding average signal intensities of (d, g) Asp, (e, h) Glc, and (f, i) Arg, using Au/HMOHs, HMOHs, and ZnO as matrices. The error bars are calculated as the standard deviation of three experiments.

elements.content: In addition, we prepared a complex standard metabolite mixture including l-aspartic acid (Asp), l-valine (Val), Glc, d-glutamic acid (Glu), and l-Arginine (Arg) to make a performance assessment comparison among Au/HMOHs, HMOHs, ZnO, CHCA, and DHB. As shown in b,c, Au/HMOHs achieve the best performance. To confirm the superiority of Au/HMOHs as a matrix more accurately, we chose three standard metabolites, including Asp, Glc, and Arg, as model molecules to conduct LDI analysis. From d–i, Au/HMOHs indeed afford the highest average signal intensities for each standard metabolite in replicate operations. Also, the salt/protein tolerance performance of Au/HMOHs was investigated by mingling the standard metabolite mixture with a high concentration of salts or proteins. From Figure S4, when a high concentration of salts or proteins exists, almost no target can be detected by ZnO, and only a few weak signals can be observed by HMOHs. On the contrary, all signals can be recognized clearly by Au/HMOHs. All the above-mentioned results indicate that Au/HMOHs hold great potential in practical use.
elements.clean_text: In addition, we prepared a complex standard metabolite mixture including l-aspartic acid (Asp), l-valine (Val), Glc, d-glutamic acid (Glu), and l-Arginine (Arg) to make a performance assessment comparison among Au/HMOHs, HMOHs, ZnO, CHCA, and DHB. As shown in b,c, Au/HMOHs achieve the best performance. To confirm the superiority of Au/HMOHs as a matrix more accurately, we chose three standard metabolites, including Asp, Glc, and Arg, as model molecules to conduct LDI analysis. From d-i, Au/HMOHs indeed afford the highest average signal intensities for each standard metabolite in replicate operations. Also, the salt/protein tolerance performance of Au/HMOHs was investigated by mingling the standard metabolite mixture with a high concentration of salts or proteins. From Figure S4, when a high concentration of salts or proteins exists, almost no target can be detected by ZnO, and only a few weak signals can be observed by HMOHs. On the contrary, all signals can be recognized clearly by Au/HMOHs. All the above-mentioned results indicate that Au/HMOHs hold great potential in practical use.

elements.content: Here, we applied Au/HMOH-assisted LDI-MS to extract UMFs from 328 samples with no tedious and time-consuming pretreatment processes. In addition to 125 HC and 141 PNS, among which the latter contains 32 subtype MCD and 109 subtype MNWT; the urine samples also include 62 samples as a prognosis group (PG), wherein diagnostic MN has been treated clinically. The information of all these samples including age, gender, and category is presented in a. Mann–Whiney U tests show that there is no significance of age and gender between HC and PNS (Tables S1 and S2). b displays the typical MS spectra of MCD, MNWT, PG, and HC, where multiple signals are included in all instances. After data pretreatment using RStudio, 639 m/z signals are finally decided for further machine learning, and the heatmap of all these signals in Figure S5 exhibits the considerable differential expression.
elements.clean_text:
UMFs on Au/HMOHs for PNS Diagnosis

Here, we applied Au/HMOH-assisted LDI-MS to extract UMFs from 328 samples with no tedious and time-consuming pretreatment processes. In addition to 125 HC and 141 PNS, among which the latter contains 32 subtype MCD and 109 subtype MNWT; the urine samples also include 62 samples as a prognosis group (PG), wherein diagnostic MN has been treated clinically. The information of all these samples including age, gender, and category is presented in a. Mann-Whiney U tests show that there is no significance of age and gender between HC and PNS (Tables S1 and S2). b displays the typical MS spectra of MCD, MNWT, PG, and HC, where multiple signals are included in all instances. After data pretreatment using RStudio, 639 m/z signals are finally decided for further machine learning, and the heatmap of all these signals in Figure S5 exhibits the considerable differential expression.

elements.content: (a) Number, age, and gender distribution of all samples. (b) Typical MS spectra of PNS, HC, and PG. OPLS-DA score plots (c) and permutation with 200 iterations (d) between PNS and HC in the discovery cohort. OPLS-DA score plots between MCD vs HC (e) and MNWT vs HC (f) and corresponding ROC curves in the discovery cohort.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Number, age, and gender distribution of all samples. (b) Typical MS spectra of PNS, HC, and PG. OPLS-DA score plots (c) and permutation with 200 iterations (d) between PNS and HC in the discovery cohort. OPLS-DA score plots between MCD vs HC (e) and MNWT vs HC (f) and corresponding ROC curves in the discovery cohort.

elements.content: An appropriate machine learning model is critical to the sensitivity and specificity of disease detection. Herein, we evaluate the diagnostic performance of several multivariate algorithms, including orthogonal partial least squares discriminant analysis (OPLS-DA), support vector machines (SVM), partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS-DA), and random forests using m/z signals from the urine samples of HC and PNS. First, we assigned these 266 samples (n = 141/125; PNS/HC) into the discovery cohort (n = 116/95; PNS/HC) and the independent validation cohort (n = 25/30; PNS/HC) at random to avoid overestimating the diagnostic performance of models. The receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves and area under the curve (AUC) values of four models were obtained based on all m/z signals from the discovery cohort. As shown in Figure S6, these four models perform great in the discrimination of PNS from HC, and all AUC values are over 0.970, indicating the high quality of UMFs benefiting from the outstanding ionization efficiency and desorption ability of Au/HMOHs. Slightly, the most satisfactory performance was afforded by OPLS-DA with an AUC value of up to 1.000, which corresponds to the best ROC cutoff value of 0.708 (Figure S7d). The evident separation of 116 NS and 95 HC in the discovery cohort by the OPLS-DA model is presented in c (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.930, Q 2 (cum) = 0.863). The permutation with 200 iterations in d displays that all right points are higher than those on the left and the intercepts of lines R 2 and Q 2 are lower than 0.4 and 0, respectively, indicating that the OPLS-DA model is not overfitted. To demonstrate the reliability of the OPLS-DA model, all m/z signals from urine samples in the independent validation cohort are applied, showing the equally excellent diagnostic results (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.941, Q 2 (cum) = 0.842, AUC = 1.000, the best cutoff value = 0.585, Figure S7). Additionally, the OPLS-DA model was also used to discriminate subtype MCD and subtype MNWT from HC based on all UMFs. As shown in e,f, the explicit group separation between MCD and HC (R 2Y (cum) = 0.926, Q 2 (cum) = 0.874), MNWT and HC (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.921, Q 2 (cum) = 0.853) from the discovery cohort is observed. All the AUC values reach 1.000, corresponding to the thresholds of 0.719 and 0.680. The reliabilities of these results are confirmed by their permutation tests of 200 iterations in Figure S8. Likewise, the thrilling results can be acquired in the independent validation cohort (Figure S9).
elements.clean_text: An appropriate machine learning model is critical to the sensitivity and specificity of disease detection. Herein, we evaluate the diagnostic performance of several multivariate algorithms, including orthogonal partial least squares discriminant analysis (OPLS-DA), support vector machines (SVM), partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS-DA), and random forests using m/z signals from the urine samples of HC and PNS. First, we assigned these 266 samples (n = 141/125; PNS/HC) into the discovery cohort (n = 116/95; PNS/HC) and the independent validation cohort (n = 25/30; PNS/HC) at random to avoid overestimating the diagnostic performance of models. The receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves and area under the curve (AUC) values of four models were obtained based on all m/z signals from the discovery cohort. As shown in Figure S6, these four models perform great in the discrimination of PNS from HC, and all AUC values are over 0.970, indicating the high quality of UMFs benefiting from the outstanding ionization efficiency and desorption ability of Au/HMOHs. Slightly, the most satisfactory performance was afforded by OPLS-DA with an AUC value of up to 1.000, which corresponds to the best ROC cutoff value of 0.708 (Figure S7d). The evident separation of 116 NS and 95 HC in the discovery cohort by the OPLS-DA model is presented in c (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.930, Q 2 (cum) = 0.863). The permutation with 200 iterations in d displays that all right points are higher than those on the left and the intercepts of lines R 2 and Q 2 are lower than 0.4 and 0, respectively, indicating that the OPLS-DA model is not overfitted. To demonstrate the reliability of the OPLS-DA model, all m/z signals from urine samples in the independent validation cohort are applied, showing the equally excellent diagnostic results (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.941, Q 2 (cum) = 0.842, AUC = 1.000, the best cutoff value = 0.585, Figure S7). Additionally, the OPLS-DA model was also used to discriminate subtype MCD and subtype MNWT from HC based on all UMFs. As shown in e,f, the explicit group separation between MCD and HC (R 2Y (cum) = 0.926, Q 2 (cum) = 0.874), MNWT and HC (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.921, Q 2 (cum) = 0.853) from the discovery cohort is observed. All the AUC values reach 1.000, corresponding to the thresholds of 0.719 and 0.680. The reliabilities of these results are confirmed by their permutation tests of 200 iterations in Figure S8. Likewise, the thrilling results can be acquired in the independent validation cohort (Figure S9).

elements.content: Encouraged by the above-mentioned results, we tried to find out specific metabolic signals with significant difference between PNS and HC from the discovery cohort. To avoid biases related to individual feature selection algorithms, we integrate multiple feature selection approaches to rank the m/z signals. In addition to those with variable importance for the protection (VIP) > 1, which is a significant parameter in OPLS-DA, m/z signals with significant variation including a p-value (t-test) < 0.05 and fold change > 2 or < 0.5 are selected. Eventually, nine highly representative signals are defined as potential biomarkers for PNS diagnosis (Table S3). As expected, the high-confidence marker panel presents excellent performance in the discrimination of PNS (including MCD and MNWT) and HC for both discovery and independent validation cohorts. From Figure S10, we observe that the AUC values of PNS (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.780, Q 2 (cum) = 0.725), MNWT (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.773, Q 2 (cum) = 0.719), and MCD (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.756, Q 2 (cum) = 0.704) vs HC are 0.986 (the optimal cutoff value, 0.438), 0.983 (the best cut-off value, 0.524), and 1.000 (the cutoff value, 0.558), respectively, in the discovery cohort. The corresponding 200 iterations confirm the reliability of these results (Figure S10c). From the blind test results in Figure S11a–c, all the AUC values achieve 1.000, suggesting the high application value of the established marker panel.
elements.clean_text: Encouraged by the above-mentioned results, we tried to find out specific metabolic signals with significant difference between PNS and HC from the discovery cohort. To avoid biases related to individual feature selection algorithms, we integrate multiple feature selection approaches to rank the m/z signals. In addition to those with variable importance for the protection (VIP) > 1, which is a significant parameter in OPLS-DA, m/z signals with significant variation including a p-value (t-test) < 0.05 and fold change > 2 or < 0.5 are selected. Eventually, nine highly representative signals are defined as potential biomarkers for PNS diagnosis (Table S3). As expected, the high-confidence marker panel presents excellent performance in the discrimination of PNS (including MCD and MNWT) and HC for both discovery and independent validation cohorts. From Figure S10, we observe that the AUC values of PNS (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.780, Q 2 (cum) = 0.725), MNWT (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.773, Q 2 (cum) = 0.719), and MCD (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.756, Q 2 (cum) = 0.704) vs HC are 0.986 (the optimal cutoff value, 0.438), 0.983 (the best cut-off value, 0.524), and 1.000 (the cutoff value, 0.558), respectively, in the discovery cohort. The corresponding 200 iterations confirm the reliability of these results (Figure S10c). From the blind test results in Figure S11a-c, all the AUC values achieve 1.000, suggesting the high application value of the established marker panel.

elements.content: In addition, we tried to identify these nine m/z signals from the Human Metabolome database (http://www.hmdb.ca/) and compared their differential expression levels in HC, MCD, and MNWT. The detailed information of these signals is listed in Table S3. From , all these nine metabolites are obviously downregulated in both MCD and MNWT compared with HC, while they present similar expression levels in MCD and MNWT. This result suggests that the obvious discrepancy of nine metabolites exists between HC and PNS instead of MCD and MNWT, which will be discussed later. To further confirm the biological significance of these m/z signals, we explored the metabolic pathways in which they may be involved. As shown in Figure S12, the pathways of nine high-confidence metabolites mainly include aminoacyl-tRNA biosynthesis, arginine biosynthesis, alanine, aspartate, and glutamate metabolism, arginine and proline metabolism, glycine, serine, and threonine metabolism, and glyoxylate and dicarboxylate metabolism. As reported, alanine, proline, and arginine metabolism can predict proteinuria progression, which is closely related to the degree of renal damage, indicating the high-confidence level of these nine m/z signals. Also, the reactive oxygen species play an important role in the induction of proteinuria in nephrotic syndrome, and the aminoacyl-tRNA biosynthesis pathway is related to oxidative stress. Additionally, the presence of nitric oxide in the kidney has been implicated in the pathogenesis of human glomerulonephritis. As known, arginine is directly related to the production of nitric oxide in the body and participates in the regulation of end-stage renal degeneration. More specifically, uric acid as the end product of purine metabolism has been normally known to impact the kidneys through causing nephrolithiasis and acute kidney injury. A recent research shows that the risk of MCD progression increases by 29% for every 1 mg dL–1 increase of the uric acid level in the baseline. Valine is one of the three branched-chain amino acids that is essential for animal health and important in metabolism, the urinary level of which is found to decrease in PNS, which is consistent with our results (). Notably, it is inevitable that all these nine metabolites participate in various renal activities. For example, valine was reported to hold potential in assessing the risk of diabetic nephropathy development, and a high urine uric acid-to-creatinine ratio was identified as an independent risk factor for contrast-induced nephropathy. As such, a combination of them still can be used for the accurate diagnosis of PNS. All these results verified the credibility of the high-confidence marker panel in PNS diagnosis.

elements.content: Distribution boxplots of nine biomarkers in HC, MCD, and MNWT including (a) glycine, (b) Val, (c) creatine, (d) asparagine, (e) Asp, (f) glutamic acid, (g) uric acid, (h) Arg, and (i) cystine. The central bars define medians, the boxes indicate the upper and lower quartiles of the distribution, and the whiskers represent the 1.5× interquartile range.
elements.clean_text: 5  Distribution boxplots of nine biomarkers in HC, MCD, and MNWT including (a) glycine, (b) Val, (c) creatine, (d) asparagine, (e) Asp, (f) glutamic acid, (g) uric acid, (h) Arg, and (i) cystine. The central bars define medians, the boxes indicate the upper and lower quartiles of the distribution, and the whiskers represent the 1.5× interquartile range.

elements.content: PNS as a common clinical manifestation of glomerular diseases possesses complex pathological types, among which MNWT is the most common one and MCD takes the second place. According to different clinical subtypes, a divide-and-conquer approach can effectively avoid illness delay and promote the precise treatment and rapid remission of the patient′s condition. Considering that the current discrimination standard in clinics depends on invasive renal puncture, molecular typing becomes particularly significant. However, the above-mentioned nine metabolites differentially expressed between PNS and HC present similar expression levels in MCD and MNWT (), suggesting that the above-established marker panel cannot be employed for the discrimination of MCD and MNWT. As a result, we continue to exert the OPLS-DA model to discriminate the subtype MCD, subtype MNWT, and HC based on all the UMFs. As shown in Figure S13a, MCD, MNWT, and HC from the discovery cohort assemble in different places in the three-dimensional (3D) scatter plots (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.922, Q 2 (cum) = 0.825). Moreover, MCD and MNWT are clustered separately (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.615, Q 2 (cum) = 0.237) with an AUC value of 1.000 (the best cutoff value: 0.479, Figure S14), which is a very exciting result (Figure S13), indicating the feasibility of PNS typing based on metabolic analysis. The blind test results of subtype classification are displayed in Figure S15a,b. The reliability of this result is confirmed by the corresponding permutation tests of 200 iterations in Figure S15c.
elements.clean_text:
UMFs on Au/HMOHs for the Typing and Prognosis Evaluation of MNWT

PNS as a common clinical manifestation of glomerular diseases possesses complex pathological types, among which MNWT is the most common one and MCD takes the second place. According to different clinical subtypes, a divide-and-conquer approach can effectively avoid illness delay and promote the precise treatment and rapid remission of the patient's condition. Considering that the current discrimination standard in clinics depends on invasive renal puncture, molecular typing becomes particularly significant. However, the above-mentioned nine metabolites differentially expressed between PNS and HC present similar expression levels in MCD and MNWT (), suggesting that the above-established marker panel cannot be employed for the discrimination of MCD and MNWT. As a result, we continue to exert the OPLS-DA model to discriminate the subtype MCD, subtype MNWT, and HC based on all the UMFs. As shown in Figure S13a, MCD, MNWT, and HC from the discovery cohort assemble in different places in the three-dimensional (3D) scatter plots (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.922, Q 2 (cum) = 0.825). Moreover, MCD and MNWT are clustered separately (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.615, Q 2 (cum) = 0.237) with an AUC value of 1.000 (the best cutoff value: 0.479, Figure S14), which is a very exciting result (Figure S13), indicating the feasibility of PNS typing based on metabolic analysis. The blind test results of subtype classification are displayed in Figure S15a,b. The reliability of this result is confirmed by the corresponding permutation tests of 200 iterations in Figure S15c.

elements.content: Simple and precise prognosis evaluation can help choose and adjust subsequent treatment protocols, so as to improve the survival time and survival rate of patients. MNWT is the most common pathological type of PNS. Herein, all m/z signals are applied to implement the prognosis evaluation of MNWT. Preliminarily, 18 CRMN and 44 PRMN collected as PG together with 109 MNWT and 125 HC are discriminated. As seen in Figure S16a, PG, MNWT, and HC are entrenched in three intervals of the 3D scatter plots (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.916, Q 2 (cum) = 0.840), and the 200 permutations prove that the result is convincing. Furthermore, the specific group separation between PG and HC (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.986, Q 2 (cum) = 0.940) and MNWT and PG (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.858, Q 2 (cum) = 0.573) is observed, the AUC values of which reach 1.000 (the cutoff value, 0.488) and 0.999 (the cutoff value, 0.501), respectively, and the corresponding permutations with 200 iterations manifest that the OPLS-DA in prognostic assessment is not overfitted (Figure S16b,c). Afterward, the CRMN and PRMN are employed as individual PG to describe the availability of UMFs toward prognosis evaluation. As seen in Figure S17a, MNWT, PRMN, CRMN, and HC occupy four different positions in the 3D scatter plots (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.964, Q 2 (cum) = 0.879) with confirmed reliability. Similarly, CRMN vs HC (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.879, Q 2 (cum) = 0.789), PRMN vs HC (R 2Y (cum) = 0.972, Q 2 (cum) = 0.921), CRMN vs MNWT (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.833, Q 2 (cum) = 0.565), and PRMN vs MNWT (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.898, Q 2 (cum) = 0.538) are clearly differentiated with the AUC values of 1.000 (the corresponding thresholds are 0.537, 0.710, 0.456, and 0.483), as shown in Figures S13b,c,e,f, S17b,c and S18 with confirmed reliability. All these results indicate that UMFs can be applied to conduct prognosis evaluation.

MNWT is the most common pathological type of PNS. Herein, all m/z signals are applied to implement the prognosis evaluation of MNWT. Preliminarily, 18 CRMN and 44 PRMN collected as PG together with 109 MNWT and 125 HC are discriminated. As seen in Figure S16a, PG, MNWT, and HC are entrenched in three intervals of the 3D scatter plots (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.916, Q 2 (cum) = 0.840), and the 200 permutations prove that the result is convincing. Furthermore, the specific group separation between PG and HC (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.986, Q 2 (cum) = 0.940) and MNWT and PG (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.858, Q 2 (cum) = 0.573) is observed, the AUC values of which reach 1.000 (the cutoff value, 0.488) and 0.999 (the cutoff value, 0.501), respectively, and the corresponding permutations with 200 iterations manifest that the OPLS-DA in prognostic assessment is not overfitted (Figure S16b,c). Afterward, the CRMN and PRMN are employed as individual PG to describe the availability of UMFs toward prognosis evaluation. As seen in Figure S17a, MNWT, PRMN, CRMN, and HC occupy four different positions in the 3D scatter plots (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.964, Q 2 (cum) = 0.879) with confirmed reliability. Similarly, CRMN vs HC (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.879, Q 2 (cum) = 0.789), PRMN vs HC (R 2Y (cum) = 0.972, Q 2 (cum) = 0.921), CRMN vs MNWT (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.833, Q 2 (cum) = 0.565), and PRMN vs MNWT (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.898, Q 2 (cum) = 0.538) are clearly differentiated with the AUC values of 1.000 (the corresponding thresholds are 0.537, 0.710, 0.456, and 0.483), as shown in Figures S13b,c,e,f, S17b,c and S18 with confirmed reliability. All these results indicate that UMFs can be applied to conduct prognosis evaluation.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully prepared Au/HMOHs through simple fabrication and calcination of MOF-on-MOF hybrids, which possess strong UV absorption, separation ability toward electron–hole pairs, thermal stability, and surface plasmon resonance effect, therefore providing high ionization efficiency and reasonable desorption of analytes during the LDI-MS process. Au/HMOH-assisted LDI-MS achieves the expected performance such as precise diagnosis, subtype classification, and effective prognosis evaluation of PNS. By establishing the optimal OPLS-DA model, PNS and HC could be discriminated completely with an AUC of 1.000 in both discovery and independent validation cohorts. At the same time, MCD and MNWT subtypes of PNS and MNWT and PG (PRMN and CRMN) are also classified successfully, all with AUC values of 1.000. During the whole data processing, the permutation tests with 200 iterations keep confirming the high reliability of the OPLS-DA model. Furthermore, taking the p-value, fold change, and VIP values into consideration, nine m/z signals are defined as potential biomarkers for PNS diagnosis. The metabolic pathway analysis of these nine m/z signals proves their close association with PNS. The understanding of the metabolic changes between PNS and HC will facilitate the development of strategies with improved diagnostic accuracy and elucidate the internal mechanisms. This advanced Au/HMOH-based protocol is expected to break into clinical practice, realize precise diagnosis of PNS, and predict disease progression, especially with the advantage of reducing diagnostic operation and improving clinical management.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully prepared Au/HMOHs through simple fabrication and calcination of MOF-on-MOF hybrids, which possess strong UV absorption, separation ability toward electron-hole pairs, thermal stability, and surface plasmon resonance effect, therefore providing high ionization efficiency and reasonable desorption of analytes during the LDI-MS process. Au/HMOH-assisted LDI-MS achieves the expected performance such as precise diagnosis, subtype classification, and effective prognosis evaluation of PNS. By establishing the optimal OPLS-DA model, PNS and HC could be discriminated completely with an AUC of 1.000 in both discovery and independent validation cohorts. At the same time, MCD and MNWT subtypes of PNS and MNWT and PG (PRMN and CRMN) are also classified successfully, all with AUC values of 1.000. During the whole data processing, the permutation tests with 200 iterations keep confirming the high reliability of the OPLS-DA model. Furthermore, taking the p-value, fold change, and VIP values into consideration, nine m/z signals are defined as potential biomarkers for PNS diagnosis. The metabolic pathway analysis of these nine m/z signals proves their close association with PNS. The understanding of the metabolic changes between PNS and HC will facilitate the development of strategies with improved diagnostic accuracy and elucidate the internal mechanisms. This advanced Au/HMOH-based protocol is expected to break into clinical practice, realize precise diagnosis of PNS, and predict disease progression, especially with the advantage of reducing diagnostic operation and improving clinical management.

elements.content:
The Supporting Information is available free of charge at https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.analchem.2c01784.

Materials and chemicals, characterizations of materials, synthesis details of tetrapetalous ZIF-L/ZIF-67 and HMOHs, LDI-MS analysis, statistical analysis, compliance with the ethical standard, references, experiments to test the properties of matrices, selection of appropriate machine learning models, performance of OPLS-DA model for diagnosis and typing of PNS, heatmap of 328 samples with 639 m/z features, pathway analysis, Mann–Whitney U test results, and information on the nine potential biomarkers (PDF)

F.S. and J.Z. contributed equally to this work.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

cln_elements.content: ZIF-L/ZIF-67 and HMOHs were synthesized according to the reported method, and the related details are displayed in Supporting Information. For the synthesis of tetrapetalous Au/HMOHs, 100 mL of HAuCl4·4H2O solution (1 mM) was poured into a 250 mL three-necked flask, and then, HMOHs (50 mg) were added and mixed thoroughly at room temperature. After that, the mixture was heated to boil. Subsequently, 10 mL of Na3C6H5O7·2H2O solution (38.8 mM) was rapidly poured and stirred vigorously for 10 min. The resulting products were washed three times using ultrapure water and dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C overnight for further experiments.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of Au/HMOHs

ZIF-L/ZIF-67 and HMOHs were synthesized according to the reported method, and the related details are displayed in Supporting Information. For the synthesis of tetrapetalous Au/HMOHs, 100 mL of HAuCl4⋅4H2O solution (1 mM) was poured into a 250 mL three-necked flask, and then, HMOHs (50 mg) were added and mixed thoroughly at room temperature. After that, the mixture was heated to boil. Subsequently, 10 mL of Na3C6H5O7⋅2H2O solution (38.8 mM) was rapidly poured and stirred vigorously for 10 min. The resulting products were washed three times using ultrapure water and dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C overnight for further experiments.

cln_elements.content:
An appropriate machine learning model is critical to the sensitivity and specificity of disease detection. Herein, we evaluate the diagnostic performance of several multivariate algorithms, including orthogonal partial least squares discriminant analysis (OPLS-DA), support vector machines (SVM), partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS-DA), and random forests using m/z signals from the urine samples of HC and PNS. First, we assigned these 266 samples (n = 141/125; PNS/HC) into the discovery cohort (n = 116/95; PNS/HC) and the independent validation cohort (n = 25/30; PNS/HC) at random to avoid overestimating the diagnostic performance of models. The receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves and area under the curve (AUC) values of four models were obtained based on all m/z signals from the discovery cohort. As shown in Figure S6, these four models perform great in the discrimination of PNS from HC, and all AUC values are over 0.970, indicating the high quality of UMFs benefiting from the outstanding ionization efficiency and desorption ability of Au/HMOHs. Slightly, the most satisfactory performance was afforded by OPLS-DA with an AUC value of up to 1.000, which corresponds to the best ROC cutoff value of 0.708 (Figure S7d). The evident separation of 116 NS and 95 HC in the discovery cohort by the OPLS-DA model is presented in c (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.930, Q 2 (cum) = 0.863). The permutation with 200 iterations in d displays that all right points are higher than those on the left and the intercepts of lines R 2 and Q 2 are lower than 0.4 and 0, respectively, indicating that the OPLS-DA model is not overfitted. To demonstrate the reliability of the OPLS-DA model, all m/z signals from urine samples in the independent validation cohort are applied, showing the equally excellent diagnostic results (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.941, Q 2 (cum) = 0.842, AUC = 1.000, the best cutoff value = 0.585, Figure S7). Additionally, the OPLS-DA model was also used to discriminate subtype MCD and subtype MNWT from HC based on all UMFs. As shown in e,f, the explicit group separation between MCD and HC (R 2Y (cum) = 0.926, Q 2 (cum) = 0.874), MNWT and HC (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.921, Q 2 (cum) = 0.853) from the discovery cohort is observed. All the AUC values reach 1.000, corresponding to the thresholds of 0.719 and 0.680. The reliabilities of these results are confirmed by their permutation tests of 200 iterations in Figure S8. Likewise, the thrilling results can be acquired in the independent validation cohort (Figure S9).

Encouraged by the above-mentioned results, we tried to find out specific metabolic signals with significant difference between PNS and HC from the discovery cohort. To avoid biases related to individual feature selection algorithms, we integrate multiple feature selection approaches to rank the m/z signals. In addition to those with variable importance for the protection (VIP) > 1, which is a significant parameter in OPLS-DA, m/z signals with significant variation including a p-value (t-test) < 0.05 and fold change > 2 or < 0.5 are selected. Eventually, nine highly representative signals are defined as potential biomarkers for PNS diagnosis (Table S3). As expected, the high-confidence marker panel presents excellent performance in the discrimination of PNS (including MCD and MNWT) and HC for both discovery and independent validation cohorts. From Figure S10, we observe that the AUC values of PNS (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.780, Q 2 (cum) = 0.725), MNWT (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.773, Q 2 (cum) = 0.719), and MCD (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.756, Q 2 (cum) = 0.704) vs HC are 0.986 (the optimal cutoff value, 0.438), 0.983 (the best cut-off value, 0.524), and 1.000 (the cutoff value, 0.558), respectively, in the discovery cohort. The corresponding 200 iterations confirm the reliability of these results (Figure S10c). From the blind test results in Figure S11a–c, all the AUC values achieve 1.000, suggesting the high application value of the established marker panel.

Encouraged by the above-mentioned results, we tried to find out specific metabolic signals with significant difference between PNS and HC from the discovery cohort. To avoid biases related to individual feature selection algorithms, we integrate multiple feature selection approaches to rank the m/z signals. In addition to those with variable importance for the protection (VIP) > 1, which is a significant parameter in OPLS-DA, m/z signals with significant variation including a p-value (t-test) < 0.05 and fold change > 2 or < 0.5 are selected. Eventually, nine highly representative signals are defined as potential biomarkers for PNS diagnosis (Table S3). As expected, the high-confidence marker panel presents excellent performance in the discrimination of PNS (including MCD and MNWT) and HC for both discovery and independent validation cohorts. From Figure S10, we observe that the AUC values of PNS (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.780, Q 2 (cum) = 0.725), MNWT (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.773, Q 2 (cum) = 0.719), and MCD (R 2 Y (cum) = 0.756, Q 2 (cum) = 0.704) vs HC are 0.986 (the optimal cutoff value, 0.438), 0.983 (the best cut-off value, 0.524), and 1.000 (the cutoff value, 0.558), respectively, in the discovery cohort. The corresponding 200 iterations confirm the reliability of these results (Figure S10c). From the blind test results in Figure S11a-c, all the AUC values achieve 1.000, suggesting the high application value of the established marker panel.

Examination and Prognosis Surveillance
by Hierarchical Heterojunction-Assisted Metabolic Analysis
